metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript Best Practices
Avoid global variables, avoid new , avoid == , avoid eval()
content.html: Avoid global variables, avoid new, avoid ==, avoid eval()

content.text: Avoid Global Variables
Minimize the use of global variables.
content.html: Minimize the use of global variables.

content.text: This includes all data types, objects, and functions.
content.html: This includes all data types, objects, and functions.

content.text: Global variables and functions can be overwritten by other scripts.
content.html: Global variables and functions can be overwritten by other scripts.

content.text: Use local variables instead, and learn how to use closures .
content.html: Use local variables instead, and learn how to use closures.

content.text: Always Declare Local Variables
All variables used in a function should be declared as local variables.
content.html: All variables used in a function should be declared as local variables.

content.text: Local variables must be declared with the var , the let , or the const keyword, otherwise they will become global variables.
content.html: Local variables must be declared with the var, the let, or the const keyword, otherwise they will become global variables.

content.text: Strict mode does not allow undeclared variables.
content.html: Strict mode does not allow undeclared variables.

content.text: Declarations on Top
It is a good coding practice to put all declarations at the top of each script or function.
content.html: It is a good coding practice to put all declarations at the top of each script or function.

content.text: This will:
content.html: This will:

content.code_html:
// Declare at the beginning
 let firstName, lastName, price, discount, fullPrice;

// Use later
firstName = "John";
lastName = "Doe";

price = 19.90;
discount = 0.10;

fullPrice = price - discount;

content.text: This also goes for loop variables:
content.html: This also goes for loop variables:

content.code_html: for (let i = 0; i < 5; i++) {

content.text: Initialize Variables
It is a good coding practice to initialize variables when you declare them.
content.html: It is a good coding practice to initialize variables when you declare them.

content.text: This will:
content.html: This will:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Declare and initiate at the beginning

syntax_highlighting.text: // Declare and initiate at the beginning

content.code_html:
// Declare and initiate at the beginning
 let firstName = "";
let lastName = "";
let price = 0;
let discount = 0;
let fullPrice = 0,
const myArray = [];
const myObject = {};

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Declare and initiate at the beginning

content.text: Initializing variables provides an idea of the intended use (and intended data type).
content.html: Initializing variables provides an idea of the intended use (and intended data type).

content.text: Declare Objects with const
Declaring objects with const will prevent any accidental change of type:
content.html: Declaring objects with const will prevent any accidental change of type:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let car = {type:"Fiat", model:"500", color:"white"};
car = "Fiat";      // Changes object to string

content.code:
let car = {type:"Fiat", model:"500", color:"white"};
car = "Fiat";      // Changes object to string

syntax_highlighting.text:
let car = {type:"Fiat", model:"500", color:"white"};
car = "Fiat";      // Changes object to string

content.code_html:
let car = {type:"Fiat", model:"500", color:"white"};
car = "Fiat";      // Changes object to string

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let car = {type:"Fiat", model:"500", color:"white"};
car = "Fiat";      // Changes object to string

content.text: Declare Arrays with const
Declaring arrays with const will prevent any accidential change of type:
content.html: Declaring arrays with const will prevent any accidential change of type:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];
cars = 3;    // Changes array to number

content.code:
let cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];
cars = 3;    // Changes array to number

syntax_highlighting.text:
let cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];
cars = 3;    // Changes array to number

content.code_html:
let cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];
cars = 3;    // Changes array to number

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];
cars = 3;    // Changes array to number

content.text: Don't Use new Object()

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x1 = "";             // new primitive string
let x2 = 0;              // new primitive number
let x3 = false;          // new primitive boolean
const x4 = {};           // new object
const x5 = [];           // new array object
const x6 = /()/;         // new regexp object
const x7 = function(){}; // new function object

content.code:
let x1 = "";             // new primitive string
let x2 = 0;              // new primitive number
let x3 = false;          // new primitive boolean
const x4 = {};           // new object
const x5 = [];           // new array object
const x6 = /()/;         // new regexp object
const x7 = function(){}; // new function object

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x1 = "";             // new primitive string
let x2 = 0;              // new primitive number
let x3 = false;          // new primitive boolean
const x4 = {};           // new object
const x5 = [];           // new array object
const x6 = /()/;         // new regexp object
const x7 = function(){}; // new function object

content.code_html:
let x1 = "";             // new primitive string
 let x2 = 0;              // new primitive number
 let x3 = false;          // new primitive boolean
 const x4 = {};           // new object
 const x5 = [];           // new array object
 const x6 = /()/;         // new regexp object
 const x7 = function(){}; // new function object

syntax_highlighting_data.text:

let x2 = 0;              // new primitive number
let x3 = false;          // new primitive boolean
const x4 = {};           // new object
const x5 = [];           // new array object
const x6 = /()/;         // new regexp object
const x7 = function(){}; // new function object

content.text: Beware of Automatic Type Conversions
JavaScript is loosely typed.
content.html: JavaScript is loosely typed.

content.text: A variable can contain all data types.
content.html: A variable can contain all data types.

content.text: A variable can change its data type:
content.html: A variable can change its data type:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = "Hello";     // typeof x is a string
x = 5;               // changes typeof x to a number
// changes typeof x to a number

content.code:
let x = "Hello";     // typeof x is a string
x = 5;               // changes typeof x to a number

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x = "Hello";     // typeof x is a string
x = 5;               // changes typeof x to a number
// changes typeof x to a number

content.code_html:
let x = "Hello";     // typeof x is a string
 x = 5;               // changes typeof x to a number

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let x = "Hello";     // typeof x is a string
x = 5;               // changes typeof x to a number
// changes typeof x to a number

content.text: Beware that numbers can accidentally be converted to strings or NaN (Not a Number).
content.html: Beware that numbers can accidentally be converted to strings or NaN (Not a Number).

content.text: When doing mathematical operations, JavaScript can convert numbers to strings:
content.html: When doing mathematical operations, JavaScript can convert numbers to strings:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = 5 + 7;       // x.valueOf() is 12,  typeof x is a number
let x = 5 + "7";     // x.valueOf() is 57,  typeof x is a string
let x = "5" + 7;     // x.valueOf() is 57,  typeof x is a string
let x = 5 - 7;       // x.valueOf() is -2,  typeof x is a number
let x = 5 - "7";     // x.valueOf() is -2,  typeof x is a number
let x = "5" - 7;     // x.valueOf() is -2,  typeof x is a number
let x = 5 - "x";     // x.valueOf() is NaN, typeof x is a number
// x.valueOf() is 12,  typeof x is a number
// x.valueOf() is 57,  typeof x is a string
// x.valueOf() is 57,  typeof x is a string
// x.valueOf() is -2,  typeof x is a number
// x.valueOf() is -2,  typeof x is a number
// x.valueOf() is -2,  typeof x is a number
// x.valueOf() is NaN, typeof x is a number

content.code:
let x = 5 + 7;       // x.valueOf() is 12,  typeof x is a number
let x = 5 + "7";     // x.valueOf() is 57,  typeof x is a string
let x = "5" + 7;     // x.valueOf() is 57,  typeof x is a string

let x = 5 - "7";     // x.valueOf() is -2,  typeof x is a number
let x = "5" - 7;     // x.valueOf() is -2,  typeof x is a number
let x = 5 - "x";     // x.valueOf() is NaN, typeof x is a number

content.text: Subtracting a string from a string, does not generate an error but returns NaN (Not a Number):
content.html: Subtracting a string from a string, does not generate an error but returns NaN (Not a Number):

content.code_html: "Hello" - "Dolly"    // returns NaN

content.text: Use === Comparison
The == comparison operator always converts (to matching types) before comparison.
content.html: The == comparison operator always converts (to matching types) before comparison.

content.text: The === operator forces comparison of values and type:
content.html: The === operator forces comparison of values and type:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
0 == "";        // true
1 == "1";       // true
1 == true;      // true
0 === "";       // false
1 === "1";      // false
1 === true;     
// false

content.code:
0 == "";        // true
1 == "1";       // true
1 == true;      // true
0 === "";       // false
1 === "1";      // false
1 === true;
// false

syntax_highlighting.text:
0 == "";        // true
1 == "1";       // true
1 == true;      // true
0 === "";       // false
1 === "1";      // false
1 === true;     
// false

content.code_html:
0 == "";        // true
 1 == "1";       // true
 1 == true;      // true

0 === "";       // false
 1 === "1";      // false
 1 === true;     // false

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
0 == "";        // true
1 == "1";       // true
1 == true;      // true
0 === "";       // false
1 === "1";      // false
1 === true;     
// false

content.text: Use Parameter Defaults
If a function is called with a missing argument, the value of the missing argument is set to undefined .
content.html: If a function is called with a missing argument, the value of the missing argument is set to undefined.

content.text: Undefined values can break your code. It is a good habit to assign default values to arguments.
content.html: Undefined values can break your code. It is a good habit to assign default values to arguments.

content.code_html:
function myFunction(x, y) {
  if (y === undefined) {
    y = 0;
  }
}
function (a=1, b=1) { /*function code*/ }

content.text: Read more about function parameters and arguments at Function Parameters
content.html: Read more about function parameters and arguments at Function Parameters

content.text: End Your Switches with Defaults
Always end your switch statements with a default . Even if you think there is no need for it.
content.html: Always end your switch statements with a default. Even if you think there is no need for it.

content.code_html:
switch (new Date().getDay()) {
  case 0:
    day = "Sunday";
    break;
  case 1:
    day = "Monday";
    break;
  case 2:
    day = "Tuesday";
    break;
  case 3:
    day = "Wednesday";
    break;
  case 4:
    day = "Thursday";
    break;
  case 5:
    day = "Friday";
    break;
  case 6:
    day = "Saturday";
    break;
  default:
    day = "Unknown";
}

content.text: Avoid Number, String, and Boolean as Objects
Always treat numbers, strings, or booleans as primitive values. Not as objects.
content.html: Always treat numbers, strings, or booleans as primitive values. Not as objects.

content.text: Declaring these types as objects, slows down execution speed, and produces nasty side effects:
content.html: Declaring these types as objects, slows down execution speed, and produces nasty side effects:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // is false because x is a string and y is an object.

syntax_highlighting.text: // is false because x is a string and y is an object.

content.code_html:
let x = "John";             
let y = new String("John");
(x === y) // is false because x is a string and y is an object.

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // is false because x is a string and y is an object.

content.text: Or even worse:
content.html: Or even worse:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // is false because you cannot compare objects.

syntax_highlighting.text: // is false because you cannot compare objects.

content.code_html:
let x = new String("John");             
let y = new String("John");
(x == y) // is false because you cannot compare objects.

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // is false because you cannot compare objects.

content.text: Avoid Using eval()
The eval() function is used to run text as code. In almost all cases, it should not be necessary to use it.
content.html: The eval() function is used to run text as code. In almost all cases, it should not be necessary to use it.

content.text: Because it allows arbitrary code to be run, it also represents a security problem.
content.html: Because it allows arbitrary code to be run, it also represents a security problem.
